Robusta coffee, known scientifically as Coffea canephora, is one of the two main species of coffee beans that dominate the global coffee market, the other being Arabica (Coffea arabica). Robusta coffee is renowned for its tough nature, strong flavor profile, and extraordinary adaptability to a wide range of growing conditions. Robusta coffee has advantages in terms of characteristics, namely being resistant to disease attacks, having the strongest aroma and taste among other types of coffee. Robusta coffee beans are widely used as raw material for ready-to-drink coffee, blends for blended coffee and are also used to make milk-based coffee drinks such as cappuccino, cafe latte and macchiato.

The roasting process is the process of forming taste and aroma in coffee beans. If we compare the ratio of coffee taste determinants, 30% of coffee taste is determined through the roasting process, 60% is determined by the cultivation process and harvest in the garden and 10% is determined by the barista when serving.

Agtron is an industry standard measurement system used to assess the level of maturity of coffee beans based on the color and surface reflectance of the roasted coffee beans. The agtron number consists of a scale of 0 – 100.

This application is the result of technology development specifically designed to measure and detect the maturity level of Robusta coffee beans. This application allows coffee roasters to know the maturity level of roasted coffee beans in real-time. This is done by detecting object images which are integrated into a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to determine the roast profile (light, medium, dark). In this application, users can also see additional information regarding Robusta coffee roast profile data and Robusta coffee beans.
At this type of roasting level, there are several roasting names that are popularly called, namely Light City, Half City, Cinnamon Roast and New England Roast.

Lightly roasted robusta coffee beans exhibit a pale, straw-like color with a hint of light brown. They maintain a dry appearance, and their surface might show slight unevenness in color, with areas of pale tan and subtle yellow undertones. The beans still retain much of their original moisture content, and there\'s minimal presence of oils on the surface. The overall impression is one of brightness and crispness, indicating a roast that preserves the bean\'s intrinsic flavors and acidity.

Light roast robusta coffee beans offer a delicate and nuanced experience. The inherent flavors of the beans shine through, showcasing vibrant acidity and lively, fruity or floral notes. The taste is often bright and crisp, with a noticeable tartness that might remind you of citrus or berries. Undertones of toasted grains, nuts, and subtle earthiness can also be detected. The overall impression is one of subtlety, highlighting the unique characteristics of the bean\'s origin.

Light roast robusta coffee beans offer a fragrant and delicate aroma. The scent is often vibrant and lively, with prominent floral and fruity notes that evoke images of fresh blossoms and ripe berries. The aroma might also carry a hint of toasted grains or nuts, adding depth to the sensory experience. There\'s a sense of brightness and clarity in the aroma, reflecting the bean\'s origin and preserving the natural essences of the coffee.

The roasting temperature for light Robusta coffee ranges from 195°C to 205°C. Roasting time is also shorter, around 10 to 12 minutes. By carefully controlling temperature and time, Robusta coffee beans can be roasted more gently thereby maintaining their brighter acid characteristics and fresh fruity aromas and flavors, resulting in the desired light profile.

At this type of roasting level, there are several popular roasting names, namely Regular Roast, American Roast, City Roast and Breakfast Roast.

Moving into the medium roast territory, robusta coffee beans take on a deeper shade of brown, resembling that of rich cocoa or a warm walnut hue. The beans become smoother in texture as oils begin to emerge and spread across their surface. These oils give the beans a slight glossiness, reflecting the light in a gentle manner. The beans might display some small surface cracks, and their overall appearance suggests a harmonious blend between the bean\'s original attributes and the flavors imparted by the roasting process.

Medium roast robusta coffee beans strike a balance between the original flavors of the bean and the transformative effects of roasting. You can expect a smoother and more rounded flavor profile compared to lighter roasts. The acidity becomes more subdued, giving way to a pleasant blend of caramelized sweetness and a moderate body. The nutty undertones become more pronounced, often accompanied by hints of chocolate, cocoa, and possibly even a touch of spiciness. The result is a harmonious cup with a satisfying depth and complexity.

Medium roast robusta coffee beans showcase a well-rounded and inviting aroma. The scent becomes warmer and richer, with the emergence of caramelized sweetness. You might detect notes of brown sugar, toffee, or even a touch of honey. The aroma is often accompanied by the comforting presence of roasted nuts, providing a sense of depth and complexity. A subtle undertone of cocoa or chocolate can also be present, contributing to the inviting nature of the cup.

The roasting temperature ranges from 205°C to 215°C, and the roasting time can take around 12 to 14 minutes. In this medium profile, Robusta coffee beans will display more balanced flavor characteristics between acidity and deeper flavors, with hints of chocolate and caramel. This creates a Robusta coffee with a stronger flavor than the light profile, but lacks the comfort of the dark profile.

At this type of roasting level, there are several popular roasting names, namely French Roast, Italian Roast, Espresso Roast, Continental Roast, New Orleans Roast, and Spanish Roast.

Dark roasted robusta coffee beans are characterized by a deep and dark brown to almost black coloration. The surface of the beans is notably shiny, reflecting light with a distinct sheen due to the generous amount of oils released during the extended roasting. The beans can exhibit larger and more pronounced surface cracks, highlighting the expansion that occurs as they roast. The dark roast beans exude an intense and somewhat rugged appearance, and their flavors are heavily influenced by the roasting process, delivering rich, bold, and often bittersweet notes.

Dark roast robusta coffee beans undergo substantial caramelization and the development of roasting flavors, resulting in bold and intense characteristics. The acidity is significantly diminished, replaced by a rich, full-bodied texture that coats the palate. Bittersweet notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, and sometimes smokiness take center stage. The inherent earthiness of robusta beans becomes more pronounced, contributing to the complexity of the cup. The flavors are robust, sometimes leaning toward a pleasantly bitter or smoky profile, providing a powerful and often bold taste experience.

Dark roast robusta coffee beans exude a bold and intense aroma that reflects the deeply roasted nature of the beans. The scent is rich and powerful, with strong notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, and sometimes even a hint of smokiness. The aroma carries an earthy quality, reminiscent of wood or tobacco. The bittersweet notes are prominent, adding a sense of depth to the aroma. There might be a robust and slightly bitter undertone that hints at the intense flavor experience that awaits in the cup.

The coffee roasting temperature should be increased to between 220°C to 230°C or even higher. Roasting time is usually longer, around 14 to 16 minutes or more. In this dark profile, Robusta coffee beans will produce a strong taste, with a more dominant bitter taste, and deeper taste characteristics such as chocolate, caramel, or even a more bitter and oily taste. The result is a Robusta coffee with a strong and flavorful profile that is suitable for coffee lovers who like bold and rich flavors.
